newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian stocks mixed, no changes forseen.
newsitem.headline: Croatian stocks mixed, no changes forseen.

text.p: Croatian stocks traded mixed in livelier business on Tuesday, and market participants said prices were likely to hover around current levels in the next few weeks.
"I don't expect any major leaps on the market. We are more likely to see trading on higher volumes than any important price changes," said Igor Kos of Taurus brokerage.
He said there were not many foreign investors who could boost the market.
"Buyers will have to make their decision at these levels. They can't wait for sellers to lower the offers," Marijana Reskovac of Karlovacka Banka said.
Seven of 18 active stocks rose, eight fell and three were flat. Volume more than tripled to 11,386 shares, turnover also rose to 5.4 million kuna from Friday's 1.2 million.
Top gainer Adriatic oil pipeline operator Janaf climbed 800 kuna to 6,400, selling 43 shares.
Biggest decliner hotelier Istraturist lost 12 kuna to 193, with 180 shares changing hands.
Most active food processor Podravka inched up one kuna to 305 on volume of 3,879 units.
All fully-listed stocks were decliners. Drugs firm Pliva inched down one kuna to 484, selling 2,216 shares. Zagrebacka Banka ordinary shares edged down 30 kuna to 2,170, selling 41 units.
Varazdinska Banka first issue lost 1,500 kuna to 44,500 but on a poor volume of two shares. Its second issue dipped 50 kuna to 1,200, with 50 units sold.

Traders singled out textile firm Varteks as a possible gainer, following the company's announcement last week that the U.S. giant Levi Strauss would extend its licence for producing jeans for another five years.
Varteks added seven kuna to 92 on Tuesday, selling 364 shares.
"Varteks is a proof that our market has started reacting to announcements made by companies," Reskovac said.
